clinicalNotes:
Chief Complaint: Chest pain

History of Present Illness:
Patient is a 68-year-old male presenting with acute onset chest pain. Pain started at 2 AM while sleeping. Describes as crushing substernal chest pain radiating to left arm and jaw. Associated with diaphoresis and shortness of breath. Severity 8/10.

Past Medical History:
- Hypertension (10 years)
- Diabetes Mellitus Type 2 (8 years)
- Hyperlipidemia
- Previous coronary artery disease

Physical Examination:
Vital Signs: BP 155/95, HR 105, RR 22, T 36.8°C, O2 sat 94%
General: Anxious, diaphoretic
Cardiac: Tachycardia, no murmurs
Lungs: Bilateral crackles

Initial Findings:
ECG: ST elevation in leads II, III, aVF
Troponin I: 2.8 ng/mL (elevated)
BNP: 450 pg/mL (elevated)

Chief Complaint: Persistent cough and fever

History of Present Illness:
Patient is a 54-year-old female with 5-day history of productive cough with yellow sputum, fever up to 39.5°C, and dyspnea. Also reports pleuritic chest pain and fatigue.

Past Medical History:
- Asthma
- COPD
- Smoking history (1 pack/day for 20 years)

Physical Examination:
Vital Signs: BP 125/80, HR 98, RR 24, T 39.2°C, O2 sat 89%
Lungs: Crackles over left lower lobe, diminished breath sounds

Laboratory:
WBC: 14,500/μL
Chest X-ray: Infiltrate left lower lobe

Chief Complaint: Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting

History of Present Illness:
Patient is a 19-year-old male with Type 1 diabetes presenting with acute onset abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and malaise for past 8 hours. Also reports polyuria and polydipsia.

Past Medical History:
- Type 1 Diabetes (5 years)
- Recently diagnosed with flu-like symptoms

Physical Examination:
Vital Signs: BP 95/60, HR 115, RR 28, T 37.8°C
General: Altered mental status, Kussmaul respirations
ABD: Diffuse tenderness

Laboratory:
Blood glucose: 550 mg/dL
pH: 7.18 (acidosis)
Bicarbonate: 8 mEq/L (low)
Serum ketones: Large

Imaging: Abdominal CT: No acute findings

Chief Complaint: Fever and confusion

History of Present Illness:
Patient is a 76-year-old female admitted with high fever, confusion, and disorientation. History of urinary dysuria and urgency for past 2 days. Now presenting with sepsis symptoms.

Past Medical History:
- Type 2 Diabetes
- Chronic kidney disease Stage 3
- Recurrent UTIs

Physical Examination:
Vital Signs: BP 85/52, HR 125, RR 28, T 40.5°C, O2 sat 91%
General: Confused, lethargic
ABD: Costovertebral angle tenderness

Laboratory:
WBC: 18,500/μL
Lactate: 4.2 mmol/L (elevated)
Creatinine: 2.1 mg/dL (elevated)
Urinalysis: Positive nitrites, WBCs, bacteria
Blood cultures: Pending
qSOFA score: 3

Chief Complaint: Sudden onset facial drooping and speech difficulty

History of Present Illness:
Patient is a 72-year-old male found 30 minutes after onset of sudden facial drooping, right arm weakness, and slurred speech. Previously independent and healthy.

Past Medical History:
- Hypertension
- Atrial fibrillation (on warfarin)
- Paroxysmal AFib

Physical Examination:
Vital Signs: BP 165/95, HR 88 (irregular), RR 16, O2 sat 97%
Neurological: NIHSS score 12
Deficits: Left facial droop, right upper extremity weakness, dysarthria

Imaging:
Head CT: No acute hemorrhage
MRI: Acute infarct left middle cerebral artery territory
Time from symptom onset: 35 minutes
